Bulgaria - Trade and Transport Facilitation
            in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Trade and Transport Facilitation in
            South East Europe Project for Bulgaria had the following
            ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: Trade
            facilitation is always a multi-sectoral and multi-agency
            activity. The replication and scaling up of lessons learned
            in trade facilitation to other sites must always be reset
            within the specific context of the site where the
            application is to take place as well as taking into account
            relevant national systems impacting on trade. Customs
            control will become more effective and efficient under
            selective procedure. The long lines of vehicles waiting to
            be processed at border crossing points are symptomatic of
            the need for trade facilitation. High Level Support.
            Building a tradition of inter-agency communication and
            information sharing as well as building the mechanisms on
            which such communication can be based, needs a high-level
            government commitment and ideally a leading person. While
            coordination issues are typically downplayed among border
            agencies, monitoring provides a sound and fair basis to
            demonstrate issues, establish a baseline, make and
            acknowledge progress, and provide an incentive to improve
            processing. The Public-Private dialogue initiated under the
            project led to significant development. A central task in
            the reform process is the formation of a new work culture.
            Not all aspects of trade facilitation are equally essential.
            Preparation time for all civil works can be very long in
            Bulgaria, following very thorough process of coordination
            among the relevant stakeholders.

Bulgaria - Trade and Transport Facilitation
            in Southeast Europe Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bulgaria Trade and Transport
            Facilitation in Southeast Europe Project aims to reduce
            non-tariff costs to trade and transport; and to reduce
            smuggling and corruption at border crossings. The program
            forms part of a regional program for the Trade and Transport
            Facilitation in Southeast Europe Project, which aims to
            strengthen and modernize the customs administrations and
            other border control agencies in Albania, Bosnia and
            Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic
            of Macedonia, and Romania. The project consists of five
            components. 1) Customs Administration (CA) institutional
            reform will finance technical services to monitor CA's
            performance and to streamline operations. 2) Trade
            facilitation development will finance the provision of
            technical assistance and advisory services to trade and
            international transport participants through the Chamber of
            Commerce, and the improvement of cooperation between public
            and private parties using a virtual forum. 3) The third
            component will improve the Bulgaria Integrated Customs
            Information System (BICIS), a regional experience-sharing
            program. 4) This component will improve border crossing
            facilities at six border posts. 5) Program and project
            implementation will finance the services required to support
            the regional and national implementation of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Trade and Transport Facilitation
            in Southeast Europe : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The review of the project components for
            the Trade and Transportation Facilitation in Southeast
            Europe Project for Bulgaria indicated that the project is
            unlikely to have significant adverse environmental impacts
            and is accordingly confirmed as a category B project. To
            prevent, minimize, or mitigate site specific negative
            impacts, however, this environmental management plan (EMP)
            and a set of mitigation measures have been prepared. The
            major concerns about possible negative site specific impacts
            associated with border crossings relate to 1) emissions from
            vehicles waiting for custom clearances; 2) drainage of
            disinfectants and spills of oils and fuel; 3) waste disposal
            and loose garbage; and 4) site disruptions caused by
            upgrades or relocations of utilities or such infrastructure
            as buildings, parking/waiting areas, and access roads.
            Specific actions to minimize any potentially negative impact
            and promote institutional development include liaising with
            environmental authorities and reviewing and monitoring EMP
            compliance; staff training and sensitization at each border
            crossing; certifying acceptable practices and impact
            minimization, especially storing and properly using
            disinfecting materials and chemicals, and hazardous
            materials and garbage; harmonizing regulatory requirements
            with European Union and international standards; and
            incorporating environmental plans in consultant contracts
            and project design.
